docs.lead_paragraph: TRY this sometime. Plaster about two dozen electrodes to your face and head and tape some more to your chest and legs. Give yourself two to three feet of wire on each, and attach the other ends to the wall next to a bed, so they tug tightly when you move. Make sure the bed is in a room that you've never seen before, something that looks like a hospital room disguised as a hotel room. A kind of Soviet-era bugged spy box for information gathering, with a video camera, pointed at the bed, blinking silently from the ceiling.
docs.abstract: William L Hamilton article on his sleeplessness and his experience at sleep clinic to determine cause; he is diagnosed with mild case of sleep apnea, one of the more than 80 identifiable sleep disorders that include restless leg syndrome and insomnia; Dr William C Dement, director of Sleep Disorders Clinic and Research Center at Stanford University, says 90 percent of our waking health is dependent on our sleep; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Sleep has become a commercial industry. In addition to pills, breathing masks and specialty bedding, there are sleep clinics, which are proliferating.

docs.lead_paragraph: One reason the Yankees want to avoid a repeat of last season's slow start is the health of left fielder Hideki Matsui. Manager Joe Torre has allowed Matsui to play every game for three years, extending his consecutive-games streak to 1,787, counting time in Japan. But Matsui was bothered by a left knee injury in spring training, and Torre called it ''an ongoing issue'' Saturday before the Yankees' 3-3 tie with the Arizona Diamondbacks at Chase Field.

headline.main: Torre Plans to Rest Matsui But Keep Games Streak Alive

docs.abstract: New York Yankees tie Arizona Diamondbacks, 3-3, in spring training exhibition game (S)
docs.snippet: One reason the Yankees want to avoid a repeat of last season's slow start is the health of left fielder Hideki Matsui. Manager Joe Torre has allowed Matsui to play every game for three years, extending his consecutive-games streak to 1,787, counting...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Katharine Jean O'Connell and Chad Scott White were married yesterday at the 3 West Club, an event space in New York. The Rev. Emily King, an interfaith minister, officiated. The bride, 34, will continue to use her name professionally. She is an assistant clinical professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Columbia, from which she received a master's in public health. She graduated from Duke University and received a medical degree from the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: There is little doubt that ''divorce takes too long and costs too much -- too much money, too much agony'' (''The Long Divorce,'' editorial, March 26). Adoption of no-fault divorce, however, will not solve our divorce law ills, unless it is accompanied by meaningful changes in how we deal with property distribution, maintenance and attorney's fees in these cases.

headline.main: No-Fault Divorce Is Not the Solution

docs.abstract: New York Assemblywoman Helene Weinstein letter opposes March 26 editorial urging NYS to adopt no-fault divorce

docs.lead_paragraph: Milana Koptsiovsky and Jeremy Sean Salzman, both lawyers, were married last evening at the Metropolitan, a caterer in Glen Cove, N.Y. Cantor Menachem Toren officiated. The bride, 26, is an associate specializing in litigation for White & Case, the New York law firm. She graduated from Pennsylvania State University and received a law degree from the University of Connecticut.
docs.snippet: Milana Koptsiovsky and Jeremy Sean Salzman, both lawyers, were married last evening at the Metropolitan, a caterer in Glen Cove, N.Y. Cantor Menachem Toren officiated.

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest private provider of health care, won a federal judge's approval yesterday to proceed with $1 billion in cuts in the benefits of its retired workers. The cuts will require more than 475,000 retirees and their dependents to pay part of their health insurance premiums for the first time. The annual cost will be as much as $752 a family.

headline.main: Cuts in Benefits for G.M. Retirees Approved

docs.abstract: Federal District Judge Robert Cleland rules that General Motors Corp can proceed with $1 billion in cuts in benefits of its retired workers; cuts will require more than 475,000 retirees and dependents to pay part of their health insurance premiums for first time; annual cost will be as much as $752 for each family (S)
